IndustryType: Processing of ferrous metals (foundries, smelting, etc.)

Title: Corus Port Talbot Blast Furnace NR 5 - RIDDOR Dangerous Occurrence 02 May 2009
LessonsLearned: <p><span style="font-size: medium">Very early on in the investigation, the Competent Authority required the operator to comply with a statutory Improvement Notice served under Section 2(1) of the Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974, that required the following action to be taken&nbsp;<em>in order to ensure the safety of employees and to demonstrate that the downcomer was adequately maintained</em></span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style="font-size: medium">&nbsp;&nbsp; <br><br>1.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A full review of the design of the downcomer on blast furnace number 5 should be carried out which should consider the adequacy of the design and whether integrity can be maintained under all foreseeable conditions of loading. <br><br>2.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;An appropriate Non Destructive Testing (NDT) technique should be selected and qualified for use in examining the downcomer in order to determine significant defects that may be present. <br><br>3.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The qualified NDT should be put into use on all circumferential welds on the downcomer, and on any other welds on the downcomer that the design review (see item 1) finds may be at risk of degradation. <br><br>4.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Suitable thermographic camera(s) should be obtained and used in order to continuously monitor the condition of the downcomer and detect leakage of gases which may affect its integrity. <br><br>5.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A system of regular visual checks of the condition of the downcomer should be put in place, the results of which should be documented. The visual checks should include reference to both the downcomer itself and to images obtained from the thermographic camera(s) (see item 4) <br><br>6.<span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A time-bound plan for the future maintenance and thorough examination of the downcomer should be prepared. <br></span><span style="font-size: medium"><br></span><span style="font-size: medium">The operator complied in full with this Notice by 16 October 2009 and is now considering replacement of the entire downcomer</span> <em><span style="font-size: medium">Major lessons learned by the Operator for the future centre around</span></em> <span style="font-size: medium">Design of blast furnace and other plant</span> <span style="font-size: medium">Management of Integrity</span> <span style="font-size: medium">Procurement of plant and quality control during construction</span> <span style="font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; font-size: 12pt">Process safety management and leadership</span></p>
EmergencyResponce_Descr: <p><span style="font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; color: black; font-size: 12pt">The company initially carried out a steel patch repair to the downcomer, which, as it was not considered as part of a formal management of change process, was poorly constructed to an inadequate design, and masked the extent of existing defects in joint 7 of the downcomer</span></p>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: <p><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">The incident occurred on Blast Furnace Nr 5, which was constructed in 2001-2002. The blast furnace is used for the making of iron as part of the steelmaking process. At 23:00 hours a large leak of blast furnace gas was seen emerging from a circumferential crack in the downcomer by an operator who heard a hissing noise. The downcomer carries this gas from the top of the furnace to storage via the dust catcher. Leakage of blast furnace gas continued for 26 hours from the crack, which measured 2.3m in length and up to 3mm in width. The operator estimates that 24 tonnes of gas was released. The location of the crack was at one of the banded welded joints made during the construction of the downcomer, the incident did not trigger the on plant gas detection system. <br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt">No ignition and fire of this extremely flammable and toxic gas occurred.</span></p>

Site_Description: <p><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt">There has been a steelworks at Port Talbot in South Wales since 1901. The location was chosen for the construction of the large integrated Abbey Works in 1947, also known as Margam. The site is located near to the River Severn Estuary and is served by deep water berths for vessels carrying iron ore. The steelworks is one of the largest in the UK. The steelworks was originally operated by the British Steel Company but has been operated by the Anglo Dutch company, Corus, since its formation, Corus is now part of the Tata Group.</span></p>
Installation_Description: <p><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt">The incident occurred on Blast Furnace Nr 5 which is the more recent of the 2 blast furnaces as it was constructed in 2001-2002 following an explosion in 2001, which resulted in 3 fatalities and 17 other injuries. That incident was reported to the European Commission as a Seveso major accident and is available on the HSE web site at <a href="http://www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/web34.pdf">www.hse.gov.uk/pubns/web34.pdf</a>. This blast furnace is one of two at this site which, according to Corus public reports, have a combined production approaching 4 million tonnes of molten iron annually. The downcomer section consists of a steel pipe, 3m in diameter, lined with refractory and made from sections of pipework joined with banded welded joints. In full production, the downcomer transports 400 000 m3/hour of top gases. The fracture occurred at the location of joint number 7, which is around 50m above ground level, there are 9 joints in total.</span></p>

Causes_Description: <p><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">The primary cause of the incident was the occurrence of a gapping circumferential crack in sleeved welded joint number 7.</span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">&nbsp;</span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">The following factors are all relevant to this failure:</span></span>&nbsp;<span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">&nbsp;</span></span> <br><br><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">1.</span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">The condition of the refractory lining which may have led to differential thermal expansion across hot spots. The top gas temperature in the furnace could reach 900 deg. C causing the steel in unprotected areas to heat up to 670 deg C in a 5 minute excursion;<br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">2.</span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">The design of the downcomer did not take into account that such temperatures could be reached, nor that parts of the refractory lining could be missing;<br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">3.</span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">Operation of the blast furnace was not adequately controlled over a number of years in that there were repeated high temperature excursions experienced in the downcomer;<br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">4.</span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">Quality control procedures during the fabrication of the downcomer, including NDT, were inadequate. This led to defects in the fabrication and welding of the banded joints that were outside of design tolerances. There were also defects in the refractory lining caused by leaving wooden stop ends in place which burned away during operation to leave unprotected steel surfaces;<br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">5.</span><span style="font: 7pt &quot;Times New Roman&quot;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span><span style="font-family: Arial"><span style="font-size: medium">Standards of workmanship found were below those expected for a structure of this type.<br><br></span></span><span style="font-family: Arial; font-size: 12pt">In 2002, the completed fabricated downcomer was transported several hundred metres at ground level before being lifted into position for site welding at joints 1 and 9 and the refractory lining may have been damaged then</span></p>

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description: <p><span style="font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span style="font-family: arial;">The outcome of the operator&rsquo;s failure to ensure that the downcomer was adequately designed, operated and maintained was a significant release of an extremely flammable and toxic gas over a 26 hour period, which was only stopped when a temporary steel patch repair was put in place.</span></span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-family: arial; font-size: medium;">&nbsp;</span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span style="font-family: arial;">The release occurred at a fracture in joint number 7 which is around 50m above ground level. The release did not find an ignition source and was not able to accumulate in dangerous quantities near to personnel.</span></span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-family: arial; font-size: medium;">&nbsp;</span></span> <span style="font-family: Arial;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span style="font-family: arial;">There were no physical injuries reported.<br /><br /></span></span></span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; font-size: 12pt; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-fareast-language: EN-US; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;"><span style="font-family: arial;">The company incurred substantial financial costs on work to repair the downcomer and comply with the Improvement Notice, and are considering whether to replace the downcomer in its entirety.</span></span></p>
